citations.narrative:
There was no Contingency Plan developed or documented by the Licensee at the time of the inspection. A written plan
should have been in place by 7/5/22.
Per this Section, dealers must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling,
treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster (one which could
reasonably be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the good health and well-being of the animals in their
possession). The contingency plan requirement ensures that the animals receive proper care during emergency
situations. Correct by 6/1/23

The outdoor pen housing 9 pigs had several plastic calf hutches/sheds that provide shade and shelter for the animals.
One of the hutches/shelters was in disrepair and had partially collapsed, and there was an approximately 12” x 8” section
of plastic missing from the top of the entryway to the hutch. The edges of the plastic along the missing portion were sharp
and/or pointed and could cause an injury to the animals when they enter/exit the hutch/shed.
Per this Section, outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the
animals from injury. The Licensee immediately corrected this item at the time of the inspection by removing the damaged
calf shed from the swine pen.

Each of the two outdoor swine pens contained a large metal water trough/water receptacle. Both of these water troughs
had a greenish brown residue adhered to the sides and bottom of the receptacle.
Per this Section, all water receptacles shall be kept clean and sanitary. Animals should have access to potable water.
Dirty water receptacles can affect the quality and palatability of the water, and the animals may decrease their intake of
water. The Licensee immediately corrected this item at the time of the inspection by emptying, cleaning, and refilling both
water receptacles with fresh water.
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with Licensee.
*END OF REPORT*
n

narrative:
2.134(a) 
   
Contingency planning. 
There was no Contingency Plan developed or documented by the Licensee at the time of the inspection. A written plan 
should have been in place by 7/5/22.  
 
Per this Section, dealers must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling, 
treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster (one which could 
reasonably be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the good health and well-being of the animals in their 
possession). The contingency plan requirement ensures that the animals receive proper care during emergency 
situations. Correct by 6/1/23 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The outdoor pen housing 9 pigs had several plastic calf hutches/sheds that provide shade and shelter for the animals. 
One of the hutches/shelters was in disrepair and had partially collapsed, and there was an approximately 12” x 8” section 
of plastic missing from the top of the entryway to the hutch. The edges of the plastic along the missing portion were sharp 
and/or pointed and could cause an injury to the animals when they enter/exit the hutch/shed.

Per this Section, outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the 
animals from injury. The Licensee immediately corrected this item at the time of the inspection by removing the damaged 
calf shed from the swine pen. 
3.130 
   
Watering. 
Each of the two outdoor swine pens contained a large metal water trough/water receptacle. Both of these water troughs 
had a greenish brown residue adhered to the sides and bottom of the receptacle.   
 
Per this Section, all water receptacles shall be kept clean and sanitary. Animals should have access to potable water. 
Dirty water receptacles can affect the quality and palatability of the water, and the animals may decrease their intake of 
water. The Licensee immediately corrected this item at the time of the inspection by emptying, cleaning, and refilling both 
water receptacles with fresh water. 
 
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with Licensee.  
 
*END OF REPORT* 
 
 n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
